Award.AwardTitle: Development of Transcriptome-Wide Predictive Models of Phenotypic Traits for Selective Breeding and Hybrid Performance Predictions in Maize
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2017. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The host institution for the fellowship is North Carolina State University and the sponsoring scientists are Dr. James Holland and Dr. Dahlia Nielsen.

Plant and animal breeding is currently undergoing a revolution brought about by big data. Methods to cheaply survey entire individual genomes now exist. Using computational models, this gene sequence data can be used to create a predictive model in which a physical trait of interest can be accurately predicted given an individual's genotypic information. In addition to reading a gene's sequence, we can also measure the strength that a gene is expressed (utilized) by the cell. The major purpose of this project is to determine if such quantitative knowledge of gene expression can be used to supplement and improve current sequence-based models. This project has potential to add significantly to the impact that omics-level data has on both plant and animal breeding, allowing for generation of superior breeds in significantly shorter time while using less resources.

This research will compare the predictive power of transcriptomic data for use in maize breeding to recently published methods that use genomic data. Existing public data will be used to guide a series of test crossed. Subsequent transcriptomic and phenotypic measurements will allow evaluation of two types of predictions: (i) predictions of phenotypic trait values in adult plants given either genotypic or transcriptomic data in young seedlings, (ii) predictions of hybrid performance given either genomic or transcriptomic data for the parent inbred lines. All data generated will be deposited in public repositories such as NCBI's Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) and Sequence Read Archive (SRA). Phenotypic information will be made available through the Panzea Project (http://www.panzea.org/)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genomic science is revolutionizing all fields of biology. The ability to probe the vast and complex molecular interactions that underlie all living cells is allowing us to advance discoveries and accomplish things that were impossible just a few decades ago. Right now, this revolution is occurring in the fields of plant and animal breeding. 

For about 12,000 years humans have been manipulating the genomes of plants through artificial selection. Every plant we cultivate for food has gone through hundreds or thousands of years of selective breeding where we continually choose the best individual plants each year and then use their progeny to populate the next generation. This simple process is extremely powerful and results in new varieties that are more suitably adapted to our needs. In the mid 20th century we began turning plant breeding into a science. The practice of large replicated trials where plants are grown and measured, combined with the application of statistical analysis, allowed us to generate accurate measurements of crop performance. This is important because crop performance can vary dramatically between two locations. This data is expensive and time-consuming to collect because hundreds or thousands of each variety must be grown across different locations to obtain high quality data. Over the last 70 years, in the U.S. we have increased the yield-per-acre of every major crop by several fold. Today, an acre of corn yields seven times as much grain as it did in 1950. Some of this increase is due to better crop management and technological innovations like genetic modifications, but much of it is the result of modern breeding practices. 

More recently, we have begun a new revolution in plant breeding where we are using data from each plant?s genome to predict how good or how poorly it will grow. Instead of waiting for many replicates of each variety to be grown and measured, we can collect tissue from one plant, determine its genome sequence and then use this sequence data to predict how well the plant will perform. We can then simply select the plants with the best predictions. These genomic-based predictions allow plant breeders to generate improved varieties faster and cheaper than with traditional methods. This process of breeding is called genomic selection. 

The purpose of this project is to explore the possibility of incorporating a different type of data into this new process of breeding. Most current methods involve using only the genome sequence. In living organisms, information is encoded into the DNA sequence that makes up the genome. Each piece of information (usually thousands of DNA letters long), is called a gene. The cell makes use of genes by reading the DNA sequence and making copies with RNA. This is called gene expression. If the cell wants to use that gene a lot, it can make lots of RNA from it and we say the gene is highly expressed. The cell can choose to use the gene a little (lowly expressed) or not at all (not expressed). This RNA expression level is another layer of information we can collect about the genome. In this project, we incorporate this expression information into our predictions.

We find that using expression data alone gives us more accurate predictions than sequence data alone. However, we also find that combining both types of data gives even better predictions. 

In addition, we have used this RNA expression data to develop a method to carry out predictions on any plant species. Before this, such an analysis was restricted to species with sequenced genomes. With our method, genomic-driven predictions can be done in species that have not been extensively studied, like less common crops or novel species with crop potential. 

Finally, we have evidence that genomic-enabled breeding can be used in the unique system of corn hybrid breeding. In this process, two diverse lines of corn, called inbreds are created. The inbreds will always produce genetically identical seed generation after generation and can be used to maintain the corn variety year after year. However, if two very different inbreds are crossed together, it creates a hybrid plant that is physically superior in every way to it?s parent inbreds. All U.S. corn production is done with hybrid plants. In this project we have shown that genomic-based predictions provide a way for a breeder to create new inbred plants in a targeted way without having to go through the lengthy and expensive process of creating many hybrids for testing. This will save significant amounts of time and money while allowing corn breeders to generate superior hybrids.
